conclusion: Understanding the problem involves an ideal gas and a graph with points A, B, and C.
Pressure at state A is p₀ and temperature is T₀; AB is parallel to the V axis indicating constant volume.
Volume stays at V₀ while temperature increases from T₀ to a higher temperature from A to B.
Point C is where the extension of BC passes through the origin.
Point A is at (T₀, V₀), B is at (?, 2V₀), C is at (?, ?).
AB should be vertical due to constant volume, but appears horizontal in the image.
Re-evaluating, AB is vertical, so B should be at (T₁, V₀), not (T₀, 2V₀).
Second image shows a red line from O to B, B is at (T₀, 2V₀).
If B is at (T₀, 2V₀), AB is vertical, indicating an isochoric process.
Extension of BC passing through origin suggests OC is a straight line.
Summarizing known points: A (T₀, V₀), B (T₁, 2V₀), C (T₂, V₂).
AB is parallel to V axis, meaning constant volume.
If AB is parallel to V axis, volume is V₀ at both A and B, contradicting B at 2V₀.
Reconsidering, AB is vertical from A (T₀, V₀) to B (T₀, 2V₀), confirming constant volume.
Extension of BC passing through origin implies O, B, and C are colinear.
Third image shows B at (T₀, 2V₀), C is elsewhere.
Considering coordinates: O (0, 0), B (T₀, 2V₀), C (T_c, V_c).
Colinearity implies slope OB equals slope BC.
